0.-Preparation.title: 0. Preparation
0.-Preparation.content:
Things to get sorted before we go

Bikes need to be road registered and licenced beyond the Expedition end date.
Original eNatis certificate is essential to travel with owner / driver.
Clearance certificate from police station – x 3 copies. Every Driver of every motorcycle must list every attachment and tool on the bike even extras such as lights.
Don’t leave loose things - Tools, GPS etc. on the bikes - bring them with you or place them in a separate bag for transporting.
Get a clearance certificate from the police that states its not stolen and it belongs to you.
Prepare an authorization letter confirming a driver can transport it to Namibia for you.

Can the above clearance / letters all be done as one ??


It is up to each bike owner to insure their own bikes and notify their insurer of the trip details.
Mike to confirm bike trailer is insured etc.
Copies of key documents (passports, ID etc.) to be made.
Medical Aid to be notified of the trip.
Bikes and documents delivered to TBA on the TBA for loading; with 4 x labelled Tie-down straps (non Chinese - preferably narrow ratchet), Shock protector.




                  
                  You want to enjoy the whole expedition, right? .... 
                  
                



                  
                  Get your body expedition ready!! ... fitness is very important to ride for 12 days over 1,900kms (that's like the Dakar, only slower). 
                  
                

Big difference riding for 3 days and 12 days of focused active riding!!!
Get your butt seasoned and hands hardened!… Go for multiple long outrides
Get some time in soft sand - you’ll thank yourself later.
Get in some technical stuff to build confidence.


                  
                  Injuries and exhaustion will spoil your trip ...  you don't want to end up in the support vehicle and peddling kitchen and campsite duties!!

                  Barry's offered his plot for us to Store / Load and do Pre-checks on the vehicles and loading of bikes on the trailer. Will send the location on the WhatsApp group

1.-Getting-there.title: 1. Getting there
1.-Getting-there.content:
A two day cross-country getting the crew, vehicles and riders to Henties bay (1,930kms) - our starting point of the Expedition.
Day 1 - The support vehicles with the bikes in tow, together with those making their way by road, will have to do the arduous journey into and through Botswana to the Namibian border via the numbing Transkalahari road. Once through the border, the convoy will overnight in Gobabis at the Transkalahari End Resort. Border crossing et al, could be a 15hour day.
Day 2 - Via Windhoek and Swakopmund to Henties Bay (780kms), stocking up en route for perishables, groceries, drinks, water etc. we’ll need for the next 4-5 days.


                  
                  Some people may fly in to Windhoek or Swakopmund instead of driving. Special arrangements will have to be made in country to to get to dropped off in Henties bay. 
                  
                



                  
                  Chris and Andrew will make their own way from PE to Henties. 
                  
                




Route

Link to the Routes

Departure point (Jhb)

Crack of dawn kickoff … Meet at Sasol Garage off N14 at the bottom of Krugersdorp hill at 5am

Border duties
Border crossing requirements / details

3rd party insurance will be need to be purchased when crossing into Namibia
The vehicle transporting the bikes will also need to take out 3rd party insurance for the transporting vehicle & trailer.
All insurance referred to above are paid on the Namibia side of the border (Not something that is an additional insurance cover from you SA insurance company)
The people taking the bikes across the border is likely to spend some time at the border dealing with with this schlepp. The things going over the border must com back - they want to check everything that was on the bike is still on and hasn’t been sold.

Arriving in Namibia

Sim card - Cell phone …



Gobabis
Overnight stop …




Windhoek
Shopping …

Swakopmund
Shopping … (fresh produce?)


                  
                  Bikes, cars containers, canisters must all be filled up - fuel and water! 
                  
                


Henties

Fantastic seaside lodging at the # First Group Desert Rose
We’re booked in here for the first and last night of our inland expedition.







Trailer stowage


                  
                  Still need to figure out where to store the trailer.

2.-Daily-schedule.title: 2. Daily schedule
2.-Daily-schedule.content:
We packed this expedition into two weeks, unfortunately with no rest day. The general aim is to get to the destination by mid afternoon to relax and enjoy the surrounds.
4 Days (1,2, 14 & 15) are spent travelling to and from Henties bay. The offroad section, which is where the real adventure is, is 12 days!

                  Estimated times are for the Bikes, excluding unforeseen crap like punctures etc. Vehicle times may differ. A large part of the route is active, meaning you have to focus, but mellow riding.

20.-Lone-men-of-Namibia.title: 20. Lone men of Namibia
20.-Lone-men-of-Namibia.content:
There are super cool stone sculptures placed around the region. These creative works-of-art are perfect for the terrain. They are all postured differently and not always that easy to spot.
They are shrouded in mystery regarding their locations and who the artist is.
I’ve demystified their whereabouts by sourcing their locations and marking their locations in the vicinity of our travels. One still has to spot them considering how well they blend in.
I think we will pass about 8 of the twenty something men.



                  
                  If you want to see the locations I've marked, refer to the map and make sure the "StoneMenEnRoute" layer of the map is turned on. 
                  
                


You should see several “Yellow men” locations on the map.
Click on the “yellow men” on the map and you should see something like…




                  
                  Want to a glimpse of what they all look like ? Pictures of the Lone-men of Namibia

29.-Major-river-sections--and--crossings.title: 29. Major river sections & crossings
29.-Major-river-sections--and--crossings.content:
Because we’ll be travelling on two wheels with support vehicles, crossing and travelling in several rivers, having up-to-date information on river levels and flow / flood risk is very important. 
                  
                

We have mapped out all the sections where the major rivers are part of our route. We will utilise local resources to inform us in on the conditions, where possible.

Huab river
Umaruru rirver
Hoarusib river
Hoanib river
Ugab


North western major river systems


Umaruru river
Day 1 & 2 - Lengthy sections


Ugab river crossing
Day 3 - Crossing the Ugab river when leaving White Lady

Hoarusib & Hoanib rivers
Day 9 Marble to Puros - second half - Hoarusib (only 20kms)

D9a & b - Alternate routes - Hoarusib (Approx. 10kms)

Intermittent stream joining up with Hoarusib river


Day 10 Puros to Ongongo - Frist section through the Purros canyon & Second half


Huab
Day 11 - Crossing


Ugab river
Day 12 - Short section  (2kms)




                  
                  We've picked August for two reasons - more temperate heat during the day and out of the rainy season. Chances of rain based on historical statistics is estimated to be around 6%. 
                  
                

We will do a rain check before we depart and if rain is predicted, we’ll adapt as much and as best as possible.

3.-Day-1---Henties-to-Spitzkoppe.title: 3. Day 1 - Henties to Spitzkoppe
3.-Day-1---Henties-to-Spitzkoppe.content:
Up the Umaruru river

We will confirm the conditions of the riverbeds prior to doing this and other sections of the route, but assuming conditions are good, we’ll travel about 80kms inside the Umaruru riverbed, hang right and head down to Spitzkoppe. There is a good chance the support vehicles can follow on the same route. If not, there is an alternate route available, but super corrugated, I’m told.
We will leave at first light to give us as much time as possible to enjoy the route and to get to Spitzkoppe early as possible - to enjoy this magical place.




                  
                  Picture yourself .... throttle twisted wide open ... wide open sand coming at you ... yeah baby! 
                  
                



Cool footage
1 - Barbara & Johan riding up the Umaruru 690 & 701 
2 - Cool zen video … Vehicles upriver - 3 Years ago
3 - If you’re not careful … Exploring the Omaruru River
4 - Cool details … Stpizkoppe then Umaruru (Reverse)

Spitzkoppe

The Spitzkoppe is a group of bald granite peaks or inselbergs. The sheer size with voluptuous curves makes this cluster formation so intriguing. The granite is more than 120 million years old and the highest outcrop rises about 1,728 metres above sea level. The peaks stand out dramatically from the flat surrounding plains.



They have great expansive campsites! There are nice outdoor showers at reception and ablutions spread around. We will have all we need so we were good to camp and have fun riding / driving around.




                  
                  There are open fire pits. Ons gaan lekker BRAAI! 
                  
                


First night sleeping under the stars … No need to bunch up - snorers can run wide here. 



Beautiful view of the night sky (Milky Way clearly visible!) …  so clear you can see tomorrow coming …




                  
                  If you're an insomniac like Rainer, you can dissolve your worldly thoughts into the deep overloaded night sky. 
                  
                



Refuelling


                  
                    No fuel station around - The next refuel spot is Uis (approx. 135kms). We will have travelled about 150kms, making the refuel point about 285kms
                  
                



                  
                  Bikes with ranges < 320kms should add a few litres from the Jerry cans, or carry a fuel 5l bladder, as a safety margin.

31.-The-River-system-in-Namibia.title: 31. The River system in Namibia
31.-The-River-system-in-Namibia.content:
Namibia Rivers Map — a general country-wide map showing rivers, major waterways and their courses. This map gives a broad orientation of where major and smaller rivers flow across Namibia.

Namibia Rivers Map


In-depth study - report on the water resources

4.-Day-2---Spitzkoppe-to-Brandberg.title: 4. Day 2 - Spitzkoppe to Brandberg
4.-Day-2---Spitzkoppe-to-Brandberg.content:
Back up to the Umaruru river, Uis & White Lady


We head back up to the Umaruru river on a different route. Do about 25kms of riverbed then head to UIS for refuelling and some refreshments.



Refuelling in Uis

We will have travelled about 285kms since the start (Henties) so refuelling is essential. It may be prudent for those with shorter fuel range  (i.e. below 300kms) to add some fuel from the storage. As a general rule … if there’s fuel, fill up.



Looks like a nice spot to quench the thirst (Brandberg White Lady Cafe)



From Uis to Brandberg (White Lady Camp site) is about 35kms further.


Arriving at the White Lady Campsite

This campsite is nice and open with hot water and braai facilities.



After the first night, the snorers are tagged … Plenty of space to avoid them …



Brandberg as seen from above … If we had more time it would have been nice to loop around it



View of the campsite from the hill above the lodge …




                  
                  .... Great place to have sundowners ... 
                  
                




                  
                  There is a restaurant, if preferable ... 
                  
                




                  
                  This is the way to end the day... 
                  
                



Refuelling


                  
                  No fuel station!  - No worries ... next Fuel Stop +/- 190kms (Palmwag). Distance since last refuel 35kms (225kms)

5.-Day-3---Brandberg-to-Palmwag.title: 5. Day 3 - Brandberg to Palmwag
5.-Day-3---Brandberg-to-Palmwag.content:
A 190km of mixed riding.



The first 65kms is a mix of rocky and some of the Goantagab riverbed at the Red Mountain Joint Management Area (up to the C39).





                  
                  Google maps and even Google earth makes things looks so flat ..... 
                  
                

Cool footage
1 - Barbara & Johan riding from Brandberg on a 690/701 
2 - A cool biking video that’s a bit long, but gives a good idea of the terrain seemingly after some prior rains - early 2025 - Route ridden top down

Organ Pipes

Formed as molten lava intruded into older rock (slate/shale), then cooled and contracted, fracturing in such a regular, polygonal pattern. Estimated to be around 130–150 million years old, making it a relic of ancient volcanic activity in the region. Over time, erosion exposed these basalt/dolerite columns, creating the dramatic “organ-pipe” effect - The result is striking: a natural “cathedral” of stone, often described as one of the more spectacular examples of basalt columnar jointing in southern Africa — a kind of geological monument to Earth’s volcanic past.



                  
                  Fee around R250 / NAM$. The visit is short —  10–15 minutes ! 
                  
                



Pitstop at Twyfelfontein lodge


                  
                  Will have earned the  coming up ... Follow this lady if you're thirsty
                  
                




                  
                  Best bar in the wilderness !! 
                  
                



Next stop Palmwag Lodge / Campsite
Camp vibes

Luxury camping and Eating out!!!






Accommodation is structured tents, each equipped with 4 single beds, an en-suite bathroom with a shower, and a kitchen equipped with a fridge, stove, sink, necessary cooking utensils, and cutlery. In addition to this, there is an outside braai as well as a fire pit to gather round and enjoy the Namibian night sky.


Refuelling


                  
                    Refuel at Palmwag! Next Fuel Stop +/- 150kms (Sesfontein)

6.-Day-4---Palmwag-to-Khowarib.title: 6. Day 4 - Palmwag to Khowarib
6.-Day-4---Palmwag-to-Khowarib.content:
126kms of really diverse and exciting riding - everything from hilly, rocky to hardpack, sandy and even fesh-fesh. Fantastic scenery going through the Klein Serengeti and the Khowarib Schlucht.



We head up the D3706 gravel road for about 50kms, turn right into this 70km section of some amazing wilderness riding. There have been lions spotted, apparently escapees from Etosha, but I’m told if we travel together there won’t be a problem.



Cool footage




























                  
                  Martin Malec: # Kaokoland 2018 Day 2 
                  
                


Video footage
Clearly this route’s ease of passage is dependent on past rainfall and current lion activity  …
1 - Scrumming - wet conditions 


                  
                  The plan was to ride 70km up the Hoanib River but 15km in we turned around because someone thought it would be funny to broadcast some fake news about lions in the river 
                  
                

2 -When its dry - very different … Excuse the commentary

Pitstop … somewhere in the Schlucht


                  
                  If the conditions are favourable and the vehicles join we will have ... 
                  
                


Next stop Khowarib Lodge (Self catering tents)
Camp vibes

The en-suite tents are a short walk from the lodge to the river bank and either have a double or twin beds. Viewing platforms extend from the front of each tent, shaded by the plentiful mopani trees but affording splendid views of the gorge. The open-air bathrooms are spacious and well equipped, adding to the feeling of indulgence and relaxation that Khowarib Lodge offers.






Lodge features an outdoor swimming pool, garden, a terrace and restaurant and a bar. All rooms come with a patio.
The self-catering units consist of two ¾ beds with bedding and towels. A fan is available to cool down on hot days. The self-catering units are made from canvas and have a porch area in front with a table, four chairs and a mini kitchenette. An en-suite bathroom with a shower, washbasin, and toilet is included. Each self-catering unit has a braai (barbecue).
Guests are welcome to use the swimming pool, bar and restaurant at the nearby campsite.


Dinner plans


                  
                  It's optional to eat at the restaurant (by prior arrangement) 
                  
                


Refuelling


                  
                    - After packing up camp we'll all travel about 35kms to Sessfontein to refuel. The next Fuel Stop is  +/- 150kms (Opuwo)

Index.title: Index
Index.content:
Namibia 2026 Expedition






























































CONTENTS0. Preparation1. Getting there2. Daily schedule3. Day 1 - Henties to Spitzkoppe4. Day 2 - Spitzkoppe to Brandberg5. Day 3 - Palmwag6. Day 4 - Palmwag to Khowarib20. Lone men of NamibiaVetenary constraints and considerations29. Major river sections & crossings30. Latest Country Information31. The River system in Namibia

Summary of the Expedition

This Expedition will take us through some of the most geographically diverse and sparsely occupied terrain in Namibia … Damaraland and Kaokoland (the Erongo and Kunene regions); we’ll be riding through and seeing some unusual landmarks like Spitzkoppe, Brandberg, Epupa Falls, Van Zyl’s pass, the Marienfluss, Purros Canyon, Kowharib Schlucht, Desolation valley and a bunch more. The best part for bikers … you will be witnessing changing conditions right under you feet every day.
While the terrain is often rough, we’ve opted for a mix of roughing it in the open and the occasional luxury lodging.  Unlike some solo travellers without support, we’ve opted to go for a little more comfort and piece of mind, making travelling lighter and agile to enjoy the time in the saddle and hopefully less fatigue in the sandy, fesh-fesh and rocky conditions. We will be supported by three vehicles who will bring along all the goodies to complete the safety, camping, catering and backup facilities we’ll need.


Map and routes


                  
                  Info
                  
                

Here are the Routes
Tracks4Africa Map - A good place to look around


                  
                  Something we have to keep in mind is the weather conditions prior to our trip, and forecast during our trip, that could influence the routes, as well as  vetenary and border regulations.
                  
                



The inland section of the Expedition.


We will travel 1,930kms over 12 days. It is a true dual sport adventure in one of the most beautiful and fascinating places on earth. One needs a  degree of sand and technical riding skill and experience covering some sand and rocky mountain passes during the trip. Fitness will play an important role as fatigue is likely to creep in at some point.
We will trailer all the bikes together, into and out of Namibia. At the appropriate time we will indicate where and when to deliver your bikes and all the mandatory documentation - of which there is a crap load.
This expedition is not to make money and is therefore on a cost covering basis. We have limited this to 10 riders, all contributing equally to the costs. We will arrange, where possible spares etc. on a return basis.


Acknowledgements


                  
                  Note
                  
                

Gratitude to Barbara Muzinski for providing invaluable guidance helping us plan this expedition, having done parts of this trip back in 2019 with Johan, but without support vehicles .
Shout out to Martin Malec and Hardy de Kock, who also shared important  information having travelled these parts on many occasions.



This expedition includes:

All the accommodation in Namibia (mostly camping)
Bring your own Stretcher, sleeping bag & camping chair
All cutlery, crockery, cooking utilities & equipment
Breakfast, lunch packs & dinner (eating out where available)
Fresh water and refreshments
Fridge / Freezer - Ice when available
Backup and recovery vehicles
Medical support / First-aid kit and assistance from George & Andrew
Aerial evacuation arrangements with an Evacuation Company. ???
Backup  fuel for bikes in areas where no fuel is available. We’ll all fill wherever possible. (budget around R2000/pp)
Tracks / Routes to upload to your GPS.
General Tools. (Note: Each biker / biker pair to carry own basic tools and tyre repair).
Tyre Air Compressor.
Puncture repair equipment.
Limited bike spares and accessories.
2 X Satellite phones (For emergencies in the remote areas, where there is no Cell / Wi-Fi)
Walkie talkies for Support vehicles & Sweeper. Riders recommended to use intercom system.


Regional map

Some arb information about the region …
Erongo Region
Erongo Region
This region comprises the Swakopmund magisterial district up to the Ugab river and includes the enclave of Walvis Bay, former Damaraland south of the Ugab river, and the Omaruru and Karibib magisterial districts. The region comprises of six constituencies: Omaruru, Karibib, Brandberg, Arandis, Swakopmund, Walvis Bay.
This region is named after the Erongo mountain, a well known landmark in Namibia and in this area. All the main centres within this region, excepting south of former Damaraland, are connected by tarred roads. Gravel roads link this this part with either Omaruru or Swakopmund.
The inclusion of former South Damaraland is necessitated by various services for this part which originate in Omaruru. Postal and telecommunications services for Omatjette, Okombahe and Uis are maintained from Omaruru. Veterinary services for these areas are provided by the State Veterinarian based at Omaruru.
The Omaruru, Karibib and Okombahe/Uis/Tsubeses areas are all situated in a semi-arid farming region and have a homogenous farming pattern, which is mostly stock-raising. It also combines communal farming with commercial farming.
Various mining operations occur within this region at places such as  Navachab
and on a smaller scale at places surrounding Uis and the desert area.


                  
                  Info
                  
                

Facilities such as hospitals and clinics, the supply of electricity and telecommunication services are, with a few exceptions, well established.
Medical services are rendered at the clinics of Omatjette, Okombahe, and Uis by medical personnel and private doctors stationed at Omaruru. The main hospital centre for this area is in Omaruru.



Kunene Region
Kunene Region
This region comprises the western part of former Ovambo, Koakoland, Damaraland north of the Ugab river and the Magisterial District of Outjo. The region has been divided into the following six constituencies: Ruacana, Opuwo, Sesfontein, Khorixas, Kamanjab and Outjo.
This region is named after the Kunene river which forms the north-western border of this particular region. With its large supply of water and its hydro-electric plant, this river will play an increasingly important role in Namibia. 
At its main centres, the region has facilities such as clinics and hospitals and electrical power supply.



                  
                  This site and information has been built for our Expedition group exclusively, please refrain from sharing outside this group.
